questions.question: A jet lands on an aircraft carrier at a speed of $68\text{ m/s}$ and is brought to a complete stop by an arresting gear in $2.1\text{ s}$. Assuming constant deceleration, calculate the distance the jet travels during this deceleration.
questions.explanation: Using $s = \frac{u+v}{2} \times t = \frac{68+0}{2} \times 2.1 = 34 \times 2.1 = 71.4 \approx 71\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A cyclist is traveling at $4.5\text{ m/s}$ when they begin to accelerate uniformly at $0.80\text{ m/s}^2$. How much time does it take for them to cover the next $50\text{ m}$?

A person stands on a $22\text{ m}$ high bridge and throws a stone vertically downward with an initial speed of $6.0\text{ m/s}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the speed of the stone just before it hits the water below.

An object is launched straight upward and is in the air for a total of $7.4\text{ s}$ before returning to its launch point. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the maximum height reached by the object.
questions.explanation: Time to reach maximum height is half the total time: $t = 7.4/2 = 3.7\text{ s}$. Using $h = \frac{1}{2}gt^2 = 4.9 \times (3.7)^2 = 4.9 \times 13.69 \approx 67.1 \approx 67\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A ball is kicked from ground level with an initial velocity of $19\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $42^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the horizontal range of the ball.
questions.explanation: Using the range formula: $R = \frac{u^2 \sin(2\theta)}{g} = \frac{(19)^2 \sin(84^{\circ})}{9.8} = \frac{361 \times 0.9945}{9.8} = \frac{359.0}{9.8} \approx 36.63 \approx 37\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A supply plane drops a package while flying horizontally at $140\text{ m/s}$ at an altitude of $450\text{ m}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the magnitude of the package's velocity at the moment of impact with the ground.
questions.explanation: Vertical component at impact: $v_y^2 = 2gh = 2(9.8)(450) = 8820$, so $v_y = \sqrt{8820} \approx 93.9\text{ m/s}$. The horizontal component remains $140\text{ m/s}$. The resultant speed is $v = \sqrt{140^2 + 93.9^2} = \sqrt{19600 + 8820} = \sqrt{28420} \approx 168.6 \approx 169 \approx 170\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A stunt driver attempts to jump a gap by leaving a ramp at $25^{\circ}$ with a speed of $32\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the time the car spends in the air if it lands at the same height as the ramp.
questions.explanation: Time of flight: $T = \frac{2u \sin\theta}{g} = \frac{2 \times 32 \times \sin(25^{\circ})}{9.8} = \frac{64 \times 0.4226}{9.8} = \frac{27.05}{9.8} \approx 2.76 \approx 2.8\text{ s}$.

questions.question: A swimmer can swim at a speed of $0.95\text{ m/s}$ in still water. They aim directly across a river that is $40\text{ m}$ wide (perpendicular to the banks). If the river current flows at $0.55\text{ m/s}$ parallel to the banks, how far downstream from their starting point will they land?
questions.explanation: Time to cross the river: $t = 40/0.95 = 42.105\text{ s}$. Downstream distance: $d = v_{current} \times t = 0.55 \times 42.105 \approx 23.16 \approx 23\text{ m}$.

questions.question: Car A travels due East at $88\text{ km/h}$ while Car B travels due North at $62\text{ km/h}$. Calculate the velocity of Car A relative to Car B, giving both magnitude and direction.
questions.explanation: Magnitude: $|\vec{v}_{A/B}| = \sqrt{88^2 + 62^2} = \sqrt{7744 + 3844} = \sqrt{11588} \approx 107.6 \approx 108\text{ km/h}$. Direction: $\theta = \tan^{-1}(62/88) \approx 35.2^{\circ}$ south of east (since A is east, B is north, the relative vector points southeast).

questions.question: A car of mass $1200\text{ kg}$ is traveling at $18\text{ m/s}$. The driver applies the brakes, providing a net braking force of $4200\text{ N}$. Calculate the time it takes for the car to come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: Deceleration: $a = F/m = -4200/1200 = -3.5\text{ m/s}^2$. Using $v = u + at$: $0 = 18 - 3.5t \rightarrow t = 18/3.5 \approx 5.14 \approx 5.1\text{ s}$.

questions.question: A box of mass $22\text{ kg}$ is pulled across a horizontal floor by a horizontal force of $110\text{ N}$. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the box and the floor is $0.34$, calculate the acceleration of the box.
questions.explanation: Friction force: $f_k = \mu_k mg = 0.34 \times 22 \times 9.8 = 0.34 \times 215.6 = 73.3\text{ N}$. Net force: $F_{net} = 110 - 73.3 = 36.7\text{ N}$. Acceleration: $a = F_{net}/m = 36.7/22 \approx 1.668 \approx 1.7\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $5.0\text{ kg}$ block is pushed across a horizontal floor. It starts with an initial speed of $12\text{ m/s}$ and comes to a stop after sliding $6.5\text{ m}$. Assuming constant deceleration, calculate the magnitude of the friction force acting on the block.
questions.explanation: Using $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$: $0 = (12)^2 + 2a(6.5) \rightarrow a = -144/13 = -11.08\text{ m/s}^2$. The friction force magnitude is $F_f = m|a| = 5.0 \times 11.08 \approx 55.4 \approx 55\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $15\text{ kg}$ block is placed on an incline that makes an angle of $35^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the incline is $0.22$, calculate the acceleration of the block as it slides down the ramp.
questions.explanation: Component of weight down the incline: $F_\parallel = mg\sin\theta = 15 \times 9.8 \times \sin 35^{\circ} = 147 \times 0.5736 = 84.3\text{ N}$. Normal force: $N = mg\cos\theta = 147 \times \cos 35^{\circ} = 147 \times 0.8192 = 120.4\text{ N}$. Friction force: $f_k = \mu_k N = 0.22 \times 120.4 = 26.5\text{ N}$. Net force: $F_{net} = 84.3 - 26.5 = 57.8\text{ N}$. Acceleration: $a = F_{net}/m = 57.8/15 \approx 3.85 \approx 3.9\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: Calculate the mass of a crate that requires a $45\text{ N}$ force applied parallel to a frictionless incline of $20^{\circ}$ to prevent it from sliding down the ramp.
questions.explanation: On a frictionless incline, the force required to hold the crate stationary equals the component of weight down the incline: $F = mg\sin\theta$. Thus $m = F/(g\sin\theta) = 45/(9.8 \times \sin 20^{\circ}) = 45/(9.8 \times 0.3420) = 45/3.352 \approx 13.42 \approx 13\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: In an Atwood machine, a $3.5\text{ kg}$ mass and an $8.5\text{ kg}$ mass are connected by a light string over a frictionless, massless pulley. Calculate the tension in the string after the system is released from rest.
questions.explanation: First find acceleration: $a = g\frac{m_2 - m_1}{m_1 + m_2} = 9.8 \times \frac{8.5 - 3.5}{12} = 9.8 \times \frac{5}{12} = 9.8 \times 0.4167 = 4.083\text{ m/s}^2$. Then tension (using the smaller mass): $T = m_1(g + a) = 3.5(9.8 + 4.083) = 3.5 \times 13.883 \approx 48.59 \approx 49\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $12\text{ kg}$ mass on a horizontal frictionless table is connected by a light string over a frictionless pulley to a $5.0\text{ kg}$ hanging mass. If the system starts from rest, calculate the speed of the hanging mass after it has fallen a distance of $1.2\text{ m}$.
questions.explanation: Acceleration: $a = \frac{m_2g}{m_1 + m_2} = \frac{5.0 \times 9.8}{17} = 49/17 = 2.882\text{ m/s}^2$. Using $v^2 = 2as$: $v^2 = 2 \times 2.882 \times 1.2 = 6.917$, so $v = \sqrt{6.917} \approx 2.63 \approx 2.6\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $65\text{ kg}$ person stands on a scale in an elevator. If the scale reads $540\text{ N}$, determine the direction and magnitude of the elevator's acceleration.
questions.explanation: The person's actual weight is $mg = 65 \times 9.8 = 637\text{ N}$. Since the scale reading is less than the actual weight, the elevator must be accelerating downward. From $mg - F_N = ma$, we have $637 - 540 = 65a \rightarrow 97 = 65a \rightarrow a = 97/65 \approx 1.49 \approx 1.5\text{ m/s}^2$ downward.

questions.question: A $4.0\text{ kg}$ sign is suspended by two cables that make an angle of $120^{\circ}$ with each other. Calculate the tension in each cable.
questions.explanation: If the cables make $120^{\circ}$ with each other, each makes $60^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Vertical equilibrium: $2T\cos 60^{\circ} = mg = 4.0 \times 9.8 = 39.2\text{ N}$. Since $\cos 60^{\circ} = 0.5$, $2T(0.5) = T = 39.2 \approx 39\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A centrifuge rotates at $3500\text{ rpm}$ (revolutions per minute). Calculate the centripetal acceleration of a sample located $8.0\text{ cm}$ from the axis of rotation.
questions.explanation: Angular velocity: $\omega = 3500 \times \frac{2\pi}{60} = 3500 \times 0.10472 = 366.5\text{ rad/s}$. Centripetal acceleration: $a_c = r\omega^2 = 0.08 \times (366.5)^2 = 0.08 \times 134,322 = 10,746 \approx 1.1 \times 10^4\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A wheel of radius $0.45\text{ m}$ completes $15$ revolutions in $4.0\text{ s}$. Calculate the tangential speed of a point on the rim.
questions.explanation: Angular velocity: $\omega = \frac{15 \times 2\pi}{4} = \frac{94.25}{4} = 23.56\text{ rad/s}$. Tangential speed: $v = r\omega = 0.45 \times 23.56 \approx 10.60 \approx 11\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $0.45\text{ kg}$ ball is attached to a string of length $1.2\text{ m}$ and swung in a vertical circle. If the speed at the top of the circle is $5.5\text{ m/s}$, calculate the tension in the string at that point.
questions.explanation: At the top, $T + mg = \frac{mv^2}{r}$. Thus $T = m\left(\frac{v^2}{r} - g\right) = 0.45\left(\frac{5.5^2}{1.2} - 9.8\right) = 0.45\left(\frac{30.25}{1.2} - 9.8\right) = 0.45(25.21 - 9.8) = 0.45 \times 15.41 \approx 6.93 \approx 6.9\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A rider of mass $55\text{ kg}$ on a roller coaster is at the bottom of a circular valley with radius $15\text{ m}$, moving at a speed of $12\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the normal force exerted on the rider by the seat.
questions.explanation: At the bottom, $F_N - mg = \frac{mv^2}{R}$. Thus $F_N = m\left(g + \frac{v^2}{R}\right) = 55\left(9.8 + \frac{144}{15}\right) = 55(9.8 + 9.6) = 55 \times 19.4 = 1067 \approx 1100\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A car of mass $1400\text{ kg}$ rounds a flat, unbanked curve with a radius of $65\text{ m}$. If the coefficient of static friction between the tires and the road is $0.68$, calculate the maximum constant speed the car can maintain without skidding.
questions.explanation: The friction force provides the centripetal force: $\mu_s mg = \frac{mv^2}{R}$. Thus $v = \sqrt{\mu_s g R} = \sqrt{0.68 \times 9.8 \times 65} = \sqrt{433.16} \approx 20.81 \approx 21\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $0.20\text{ kg}$ mass is tied to a string and swung in a horizontal circle of radius $0.75\text{ m}$. If the string breaks when the tension reaches $50\text{ N}$, calculate the maximum possible frequency of rotation.
questions.explanation: For horizontal circular motion, $T = m\omega^2 r = m(4\pi^2 r f^2)$. Solving for $f$: $f = \sqrt{\frac{T}{4\pi^2 r m}} = \sqrt{\frac{50}{4\pi^2 \times 0.75 \times 0.20}} = \sqrt{\frac{50}{4 \times 9.87 \times 0.15}} = \sqrt{\frac{50}{5.922}} = \sqrt{8.44} \approx 2.91 \approx 2.9\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Calculate the gravitational force between a planet of mass $5.0\times 10^{24}\text{ kg}$ and its moon of mass $2.0\times 10^{22}\text{ kg}$ if the distance between their centers is $4.0\times 10^8\text{ m}$. Use $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\text{ N·m}^2/\text{kg}^2$.
A satellite orbits a planet at a distance where the gravitational field strength is $3.2\text{ m/s}^2$. If the satellite has a mass of $450\text{ kg}$, calculate the gravitational force acting on it.
questions.explanation: Gravitational force is simply $F = mg = 450 \times 3.2 = 1440 \approx 1.4 \times 10^3\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A sled of mass $18\text{ kg}$ is pulled a distance of $25\text{ m}$ across a horizontal surface at a constant speed. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the sled and the surface is $0.14$, calculate the work done by the pulling force.
questions.explanation: At constant speed, the pulling force equals the friction force: $F_{pull} = f_k = \mu_k mg = 0.14 \times 18 \times 9.8 = 0.14 \times 176.4 = 24.7\text{ N}$. Work done: $W = Fd = 24.7 \times 25 \approx 617.5 \approx 620\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A hockey puck of mass $0.16\text{ kg}$ is moving at $24\text{ m/s}$ when it hits a patch of rough ice and slows to $14\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the work done by friction on the puck.
questions.explanation: Work done equals change in kinetic energy: $W = \Delta KE = \frac{1}{2}m(v_f^2 - v_i^2) = 0.5 \times 0.16 \times (14^2 - 24^2) = 0.08 \times (196 - 576) = 0.08 \times (-380) = -30.4 \approx -30\text{ J}$.

questions.question: How much work is required to bring a $1600\text{ kg}$ vehicle traveling at $100\text{ km/h}$ to a complete stop?
questions.explanation: First convert speed to m/s: $v = 100 \times \frac{1000}{3600} = 27.78\text{ m/s}$. The work required equals the initial kinetic energy: $W = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5 \times 1600 \times (27.78)^2 = 800 \times 771.6 = 617,280 \approx 6.17 \times 10^5 \approx 6.2 \times 10^5\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $2.0\text{ kg}$ mass is attached to a vertical spring with spring constant $k = 350\text{ N/m}$. If the mass is released from the point where the spring is unstretched, calculate its speed after it has fallen $0.15\text{ m}$.
questions.explanation: At $x = 0.15\text{ m}$, gravitational potential energy lost = $mgh = 2.0 \times 9.8 \times 0.15 = 2.94\text{ J}$. Spring potential energy gained = $\frac{1}{2}kx^2 = 0.5 \times 350 \times (0.15)^2 = 175 \times 0.0225 = 3.94\text{ J}$. Since the spring potential energy gained exceeds the gravitational potential energy lost, the mass cannot reach $0.15\text{ m}$ and will stop before that point. Therefore its speed at $0.15\text{ m}$ is $0\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $0.40\text{ kg}$ ball is thrown from a $12\text{ m}$ high balcony with an initial speed of $8.0\text{ m/s}$. If it reaches the ground with $45\text{ J}$ of kinetic energy, calculate the amount of energy lost to air resistance during the fall.
questions.explanation: Initial total energy: $E_i = mgh + \frac{1}{2}mv_i^2 = 0.4(9.8)(12) + 0.5(0.4)(8)^2 = 47.04 + 12.8 = 59.84\text{ J}$. Final kinetic energy is $45\text{ J}$. Energy lost to air resistance: $59.84 - 45 = 14.84 \approx 15\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $0.75\text{ HP}$ motor ($1\text{ HP} = 746\text{ W}$) is used to lift a $120\text{ kg}$ crate vertically at a constant speed. Calculate the time required to lift the crate a vertical distance of $5.5\text{ m}$.
questions.explanation: Motor power: $P = 0.75 \times 746 = 559.5\text{ W}$. Work done: $W = mgh = 120 \times 9.8 \times 5.5 = 120 \times 53.9 = 6468\text{ J}$. Time: $t = W/P = 6468/559.5 \approx 11.56 \approx 12\text{ s}$.

questions.question: A car experiences a total resistive force of $650\text{ N}$ while moving at a constant speed of $28\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the power output of the engine in $\text{kW}$.
questions.explanation: At constant speed, the engine's power output equals $P = Fv = 650 \times 28 = 18,200\text{ W} = 18.2 \approx 18\text{ kW}$.

questions.question: A spring is compressed by $12\text{ cm}$ when a $45\text{ N}$ force is applied. Calculate the elastic potential energy stored when the spring is compressed by $20\text{ cm}$.
questions.explanation: First find spring constant: $k = F/x = 45/0.12 = 375\text{ N/m}$. Then elastic potential energy at $x = 0.20\text{ m}$: $EPE = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 = 0.5 \times 375 \times (0.20)^2 = 187.5 \times 0.04 = 7.5\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $5.0\text{ kg}$ mass is hung from a vertical spring, stretching it by $18\text{ cm}$. Calculate the work required to stretch the spring an additional $10\text{ cm}$ (i.e., from $18\text{ cm}$ to $28\text{ cm}$).
A $0.45\text{ kg}$ soccer ball moving North at $12\text{ m/s}$ hits a stationary $0.45\text{ kg}$ soccer ball. If the first ball stops after the collision, calculate the velocity of the second ball.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $m_1u_1 + m_2u_2 = m_1v_1 + m_2v_2$. Substituting: $0.45(12) + 0.45(0) = 0.45(0) + 0.45v_2 \rightarrow 5.4 = 0.45v_2 \rightarrow v_2 = 5.4/0.45 = 12\text{ m/s}$ (North).

questions.question: A truck of mass $2500\text{ kg}$ traveling at $15\text{ m/s}$ collides head-on with a stationary car of mass $1100\text{ kg}$. If they lock together after the collision, calculate the decrease in total kinetic energy.
A $4.5\text{ kg}$ projectile at rest explodes into two pieces. One piece of mass $1.5\text{ kg}$ flies East at $32\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the velocity of the other piece.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $0 = m_1v_1 + m_2v_2$. Substituting: $0 = 1.5(32) + (4.5 - 1.5)v_2 = 48 + 3v_2 \rightarrow v_2 = -48/3 = -16\text{ m/s}$. The negative sign indicates West.

questions.question: A $15\text{ V}$ battery is connected to three resistors in series: $R_1 = 10\Omega$, $R_2 = 20\Omega$, and $R_3 = 30\Omega$. Calculate the voltage drop across $R_2$.
questions.explanation: Total resistance: $R_T = 10 + 20 + 30 = 60\Omega$. Current: $I = V/R_T = 15/60 = 0.25\text{ A}$. Voltage across $R_2$: $V_2 = IR_2 = 0.25 \times 20 = 5.0\text{ V}$.

questions.question: Two resistors are connected in series and have a total resistance of $150\Omega$. If the current in the circuit is $0.080\text{ A}$ and the voltage across one resistor is $3.2\text{ V}$, calculate the resistance of the other resistor.
questions.explanation: Resistance of the known resistor: $R_1 = V/I = 3.2/0.080 = 40\Omega$. Since the total resistance is $150\Omega$, the other resistor must be $R_2 = R_T - R_1 = 150 - 40 = 110\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the equivalent resistance of a $45\Omega$ resistor and a $90\Omega$ resistor connected in parallel.
questions.explanation: For two resistors in parallel: $R_{eq} = \frac{R_1 R_2}{R_1 + R_2} = \frac{45 \times 90}{45 + 90} = \frac{4050}{135} = 30\Omega$.

questions.question: Three identical resistors are connected in parallel to a $12\text{ V}$ source. If the total current drawn from the source is $1.5\text{ A}$, calculate the resistance of each resistor.
questions.explanation: Equivalent resistance: $R_{eq} = V/I = 12/1.5 = 8\Omega$. For three identical resistors in parallel, $R_{eq} = R/3$, so $R = 3R_{eq} = 3 \times 8 = 24\Omega$.

questions.question: A $12\Omega$ resistor is connected in series with a parallel combination of two $12\Omega$ resistors. If the circuit is powered by a $24\text{ V}$ source, calculate the total current.
questions.explanation: The two $12\Omega$ resistors in parallel give $R_p = \frac{12 \times 12}{12+12} = \frac{144}{24} = 6\Omega$. Total resistance: $R_T = 12 + 6 = 18\Omega$. Total current: $I = V/R_T = 24/18 \approx 1.33 \approx 1.3\text{ A}$.

questions.question: In a series-parallel circuit, the total resistance is $50\Omega$. If a $20\Omega$ resistor is connected in series with two identical resistors in parallel, find the resistance of each of the parallel resistors.
questions.explanation: The parallel combination must have resistance $R_p = R_T - 20 = 50 - 20 = 30\Omega$. For two identical resistors in parallel, $R_p = R/2$, so $R = 2R_p = 2 \times 30 = 60\Omega$.

questions.question: A string has a linear mass density of $0.025\text{ kg/m}$ and is under a tension of $90\text{ N}$. Calculate the frequency of a wave on this string that has a wavelength of $0.40\text{ m}$.
questions.explanation: Wave speed on the string: $v = \sqrt{T/\mu} = \sqrt{90/0.025} = \sqrt{3600} = 60\text{ m/s}$. Frequency: $f = v/\lambda = 60/0.40 = 150\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: A wave travels a distance of $12\text{ m}$ in $3.5\text{ s}$. If the frequency of the wave is $4.0\text{ Hz}$, calculate the distance between two consecutive crests (the wavelength).
questions.explanation: Wave speed: $v = d/t = 12/3.5 = 3.429\text{ m/s}$. Wavelength: $\lambda = v/f = 3.429/4.0 \approx 0.857 \approx 0.86\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A police siren emits a tone with frequency $550\text{ Hz}$. If the police car is moving away from a stationary observer at a speed of $28\text{ m/s}$, calculate the frequency heard by the observer. The speed of sound is $343\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For a source receding from a stationary observer, $f' = f\frac{v}{v + v_s} = 550 \times \frac{343}{343 + 28} = 550 \times \frac{343}{371} = 550 \times 0.9245 \approx 508.5 \approx 510\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Two speakers emit sound in phase. A listener at a point where the path difference from the speakers is $2.2\text{ m}$ hears constructive interference. Calculate the lowest possible frequency of the sound. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For constructive interference, $\Delta x = n\lambda$, where $n = 1, 2, 3, \ldots$. The lowest frequency corresponds to the longest wavelength, which occurs when $n = 1$. Thus $\lambda = \Delta x = 2.2\text{ m}$. Then $f = v/\lambda = 340/2.2 \approx 154.5 \approx 150\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: An air column in a tube closed at one end is $0.75\text{ m}$ long. Calculate the frequency of the third harmonic for this tube. The speed of sound is $344\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For a closed pipe, the harmonic frequencies are given by $f_n = \frac{nv}{4L}$ where $n = 1, 3, 5, \ldots$. For the third harmonic, $n = 3$, so $f_3 = \frac{3v}{4L} = \frac{3 \times 344}{4 \times 0.75} = \frac{1032}{3} = 344 \approx 340\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Two sound sources produce frequencies of $320\text{ Hz}$ and $324\text{ Hz}$. How many beats will be heard in a $10\text{ s}$ interval?
questions.explanation: The beat frequency is $f_{beat} = |324 - 320| = 4\text{ Hz}$. This means 4 beats occur each second. In 10 seconds, the number of beats is $4 \times 10 = 40$.
